Location: Moturua Island Archaeological Site, Bay of Islands
Recommended Reason: Archaic Maori settlement site with shell pendant from tropical Pacific, one of earliest Polynesian settlements in New Zealand c.1300 CE
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological excavations revealed tropical shell pendant, storage pits for kumara, successive occupation periods indicating long-term settlement

Location: Great Barrier Island Pa Sites, Auckland
Recommended Reason: Multiple fortified Maori settlements (pa) from 16th-19th centuries with traditional artifacts and potentially undiscovered taonga
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological sites Haratonga (t8/2) and Okiwi (s8/34, s8/35) documented by Heritage New Zealand with c.16th-19th century occupation

Recommended Reason: Unique Moriori culture artifacts from c.1500 CE settlement by Maori from mainland, distinct cultural development and taonga
Supporting Evidence: Separate Moriori people developed from mainland Maori around 1500 CE, J.R. Barker Hapupu National Historic Reserve documented

Recommended Reason: 13th century to 1820s Maori occupation with extensive archaeological evidence including storage pits, terraces, and artifacts
Supporting Evidence: Continuous occupation from c.13th century documented by Heritage New Zealand, well-preserved archaeological landscape

Recommended Reason: 13th century to 1860s occupation site with both Maori pa and later European fortifications, potential for buried taonga
Supporting Evidence: Long-term occupation from 13th century through European contact, strategic location with defensive importance

Location: Eastland Port Gisborne 14th Century Village Site
Recommended Reason: 14th century Maori village site with obsidian tools and artifacts, historically significant as first Maori landing place in 1350
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological excavation yielded obsidian flake tools and village remains, believed to be first Maori landing site in district

Location: Raoul Island East Polynesian Sites, Kermadec Islands
Recommended Reason: 14th-18th century East Polynesian archaeological landscape, remote location may have preserved important artifacts
Supporting Evidence: Heritage New Zealand documented East Polynesian archaeological sites from 14th-18th centuries on remote island

Location: Traditional Maori Treasure Box Sites, Various North Island Locations
Recommended Reason: Carved feather boxes (wakahuia) traditionally suspended from house rafters to protect valuable taonga including Huia feathers and greenstone
Supporting Evidence: Traditional Maori treasure boxes contained most precious possessions including rare Huia feathers, jade ornaments, and ancestral artifacts

Location: Soapstone Bird Sites, Various South Island Locations
Recommended Reason: Sources of soapstone used for carving Zimbabwe Birds (New Zealand's national symbol), potential for undiscovered carved artifacts
Supporting Evidence: Eight famous soapstone birds found at various sites, carved figures represent ancestors and hold deep spiritual significance

Location: Historic Greenstone (Pounamu) Trade Routes, South Island
Recommended Reason: Traditional sources and trade routes for highly prized greenstone/jade, potential for cached or lost valuable pieces
Supporting Evidence: Greenstone traditionally New Zealand's most precious material, elaborate trade networks, hei tiki and tools found throughout islands
